title: What percentage of your brain do you use? - Richard E. Cytowic

comments.text:
In case you haven't seen a medical drama in the past O-30 years, you might 
not be aware that doctors now have machines that can see inside peoples 
brains and, contrary to popular belief, 90% don't just sit around all day 
doing nothing. While scientist don't yet know what each part does they do 
know that they all matter.
So if you think that a person could go inside your brain scoop up 90% out 
and you'd still be just fine, then yeah maybe you do really only use 10% of 
YOUR brain..﻿
comments.author: Rufa Abdalla

comments.text:
*What percentage of our brain do humans use?*
If you said 10%, you join the 2/3 of the population who answered this 
question incorrectly! Popular movies like "Lucy" and "Limitless" and 
countless other fiction have reproduced this myth for the past century. The 
fact is that we use 100% of our brain, 100% of the time! Here's a great 
video explaining how our brains work, setting straight other brain myths, 
like the idea of multitasking (which is not very suited to the way our 
brains process and hold information). 

#socialscience #psychology﻿
comments.author: Social Science Insights

comments.text: :-o didnt know ty <3﻿
comments.author: Hamburguer Suculento

comments.text: I watched until he pronounced it "sign-apses."﻿
comments.author: Doobie Doo

comments.text:
It's always edgy when "scientifically literate" people try to debunk this 
myth.
Guy who doesn't understand the myth says at 0:05 "An enduring myth says we 
only use 10% of our brain"
But the real myth comes at 0:32 "Most of us do not meet our mental 
POTENTIAL"
There's a huge difference, which the author of this video doesnt seem to 
understand, between using your brain and using your brain's full potential. 
Let alone your mental potential!
Here's an example, I 'USE' my car whenever I drive to school but Im not 
meeting my car's 'POTENTIAL' of transporting up to 4 other passengers! Got 
it? 
We use all parts of our brain, correct. But it's incredibly insane to think 
that we use our brain's whole capability. What do you think happens when 
you're on a test and forget that answer you know you studied? The neural 
pathway created for that specific knowledge got weakened. Imagine if neural 
pathways didn't weaken at all. You could access information you only 
revised once, you could know exactly what happened on this day 10 years ago 
or at ANY given time. 
This is a great myth, and if more scientists believed in it maybe they 
could find a way to fully transport up to 4 passengers in that thing we 
call brain.﻿

comments.author: EmXtraMoney

comments.text: +Benjamin Wilde makes sense. Preciate the breakdown.
comments.author: EmXtraMoney

comments.text:
+EmXtraMoney Those percentages represent the daily glucose consumption of 
the brain compared to each individual's body mass. That means if a brain 
consumes X glucose, in a body that has body mass equal to 50 kg, the 
percentage is much higher than X in a body that has body mass equal to 
100kg. X represents the same quantity of daily glucose. 

More exactly, a lower body mass means less resources, so a higher 
percentage of consumption is acquired. But only the percentage changes, 
while the quantity remains the same. For example, if you have two buckets 
filled with water, one that contains 500 l, and the other 200 l, and you 
need to drink 100 l to live; if you drink from the 500 l bucket, that means 
that you used 20%, whereas if you drink from the 200 l bucket, that means 
that you used 50%.

comments.author: subh1

comments.text:
You sure that it would overheat? I think the energy transfer in cells is 
very efficient and very little (and I believe almost none) energy is 
released as heat. Though I am not entirely certain. :)
comments.author: manish goel

comments.text:
Practically it will over-heat, get over-exhausted and the cells will start 
to die.
Now, just for the sake of argument, assume that you can somehow make the 
cells such that they can survive in this overheated and exhaustive mode. 
Then, all that processing of information throughout the entire brain will 
be highly unstructured, will be extremely jumbled up, and will not contain 
any meaningful, structured information or processing. Just a bunch of 
active neurons and electric currents do not make the brain what it is -- 
the structure in that information and the sequential pattern in the 
processing of it does.
As an analogy, just having more matter packed in a region does not make 
complex structures such as life forms easier to make. It requires the 
wiggle room for that to happen.
comments.author: subh1

comments.text:
+manish goel Definitely a discussable question. There were lots of smart 
reasonings given by many folks above. I think you need a little more open 
mindedness to absorb and analyse their views. Different tasks require 
different sets of neurons to fire and it is a highly inter-connected 
network. Even if you are able to supply the brain with infinite energy or 
even just over-feed, it is of no use because you cannot simply force a 
brain to work harder. When was the last time your brain was activated many 
folds just because you ate too much food? You have to ask yourself whether 
activating the whole brain is really necessary. Why would you want to drive 
a car home and at the same time cook or to remember your nightmares, and 
millions of other things? The perception will simply be too chaotic and 
will lead to nothing but failure in what you had to do (i.e. drive home). 
Most multi-tasking would most likely involve some common set of neurons to 
fire. If there is a over-lap of inputs from two different tasks on the same 
neuron/set of neurons, the brain will automatically tag confusion and you 
cannot perform well. There is reason to how our brain has evolved in this 
way to be better efficient in one work at a time. I love the human brain as 
it is. It's just that we have to understand how it works in order to excel 
at our tasks.
comments.author: Raju Gurung

comments.text:
I really enjoyed how much your question made me think Manish. I would guess 
based on the information on how the human brain works from this video that 
if 100% of our brain was active at any given moment, so as to say that 
there was a current running though all of the billions and billions of 
connections in the brain, we would lose touch with "the real world" as 
Jonathan Lyng mentioned before me, but in a much deeper sense. I believe 
this level of interconnectedness between the full scope of our memories, 
and the complete awareness of the present moment would greatly affect our 
sense of reality. I believe a brain of this type would begin to perceive 
those parts of reality that are normally much too subtle to grasp, like 
seeing the effect of time in evolutionary theory. Perception of time for 
that matter might change altogether with the person being able to 
accurately determine futures due to the combination of complete awareness 
between all their past experiences and present positioning.  In quantum 
mechanics there is an experimentally proven phenomena called the 
measurement problem, roughly speaking it describes how the act of measuring 
a body at the quantum scale actually alters its state, classic example 
being a cat in a box that you can't tell is dead or alive unless you open 
the box and look inside. In quantum mechanics, that cat is both dead and 
alive at the same time until you check, and I think a brain with 100% 
activity would perceive the world in that way, it would have the capability 
to see the superposition of all the states of the universe. It would 
effectively be a 4th dimensional perception mechanism.
comments.author: Morgan Jones

comments.text:

but that's my two cents. :)
comments.author: Jonathan Lyng

comments.text:
+Jonathan Lyng Yeah, I am actually thinking beyond the human level. It is 
just a free hypothetical question. What would happen if somehow the 100% of 
brain gets active? I am not considering, whether it is possible or not, 
whether it is beneficial or not, should we do it or not. I am only curious 
about, what would happen. Will our brain explode at that level? Would we 
have something like heart-attack? Would we become super intelligent? Or 
would it now affect us at all?
comments.author: manish goel

comments.text:
+Richard E. Cytowic  First of all, I am honored that you find my idea 
interesting.
Well, I never actually thought about how to supply infinite energy as I am 
more curious about what could we achive if we somehow do it. What would be 
the capabilities or limitiations of brain in such a scenario.
Anyway, I would try to answer your question to the best of my understanding.
I dont think that applying infinite energy instantaneously (using 
electricity etc) would do any good. The "10% at a time" limitation is 
induced by nature so that the body could sustain energy hungry brain. But, 
what if we start overfeeding it. Brain feeds on glucose like the entire 
body. An athelete needs extra glucose cause he consumes more. Same can be 
the case with brain. If we supply increased amount of sugar in a controlled 
way and force our brain to "exercise", that is to activate more than one of 
regions at a particular instant, we might be able to extend the limits. I 
guess, what I meant to say is to force the brain to evolve. It would take 
years to make changes, but I dont think that million years of evolution 
could be reversed in seconds. The possible faults in the idea:
1) altering glucose balance can be harmful.
2) changes in an individual wont be transferred to its progeny, i.e. 
everything would need to be started again.
3) Brain might not actually change.

Now, if we are impatient and we want to do it in seconds only. Then, we can 
flood our brain with 'some' molecule which can act as an alternative source 
of energy for neurons and has the property of ~100% renewability based on 
energy input from other source of unharmful energy. UV rays can cause DNA 
mutation, it might be possible to find a energy providing molecule which 
replenishes itself using energy from, for example: ultrasound.
comments.author: manish goel

comments.text:
I get were you are going but I fear you are getting far from what makes 
humans humans. think about why you cease to breathe when something is 
breathtaking, and you'll get closer to why that higher brain function you 
are seeking might just be a worst nightmare, you are also giving to much 
value tosimple energy intake, don't forget: it has limited space, veins 
going to and fro have a limited diameter and most importantly it needs 
oxygen in a limited way, to much and your brain shuts down, too little and 
your brain shuts down (same thing with energy). and before you put an 
electrode to your head, electricity is not the way the brain get energy but 
relay signals.... those are two very different things.
comments.author: Jonathan Lyng

comments.text:
+Jonathan Lyng First of all, I would like to let you know that Human Brain 
is far more superior than any computer in multitasking, computers are 
better in doing repetitive taks. Anyway, coming back to the main question. 
Human brain suffer from lack of attention. We cant focus on the everything 
we see, we cant keep in mind everything we hear, we smell many things but 
we cant identify them till we actually set our attention to it, we even 
seize to breathe when watching something very exciting/interesting (it 
might be possible that it happens to me only, but "breathtaking" is a 
common word). Now, if we are using the entire brain simultaneously i.e. 
100% brain usage, would this overcome these limitations? Would we be able 
to do deep thinking (analytical part of brain), swim (motor action control 
center) and as well as memorize what is being played on the radio?
comments.author: manish goel

comments.text:
An interesting question, Manesh. But how do you propose to "apply infinite 
energy to the brain?" Relatively speaking, electroshock, lightning strikes, 
and the electric chair deliver infinite energy to the brain and destroy it. 
Even electrode implants first Parkinson's disease or seizure management 
disrupt intrinsic energy circuits; these external sources do not add energy 
to the nervous system.
   How, then, might you imagine overcoming the intrinsic power limitations, 
as well as a thermodynamic limits?
    Much research already shows that multitasking degrades performance, 
especially in those who believe themselves to be excellent at it. So, how 
do you get past this empirical finding as well as "force" multiple regions 
to work simultaneously? They already do, except not all at once which is 
the point of the brain's energy efficiency.
     Your idea has merit, and I'd like to hear how you propose implementing 
it in a practical way.
comments.author: Richard E. Cytowic

comments.text:
But we already use 100% of our brain (not simultaneously) and we already 
are capable of stimulate multiple regions together (you do drive+sing to a 
tune+think about dinner at the same time). You really do not need more than 
this. The crazy multitasking capacity of computers is not something human 
beings should necessarily seek. It's not very interesting IRL and look at 
it this way: you already have one of the best computing device between your 
two ears, it has gone through trial and error for millions of generations. 
Many animals have two cores ( dolphins have half the brain sleeping for a 
few hours and the other half for a few more hours, a lot of birds too) yet 
those animals have a lower intelligence than humans. There maybe is a 
purely efficiency based reason for not being able to multitask or only have 
1/2 sleep times like those animals)
comments.author: Jonathan Lyng

comments.text:
+Jonathan Lyng The brain has different regions for different tasks. There 
are different specific regions for motor actions, for senses, for 
involuntary actions and so on. Using 100% brain should not mean using 
entire brain in one task. What I was thinking that 100% of brain use would 
make us much much better in multi-tasking, as we would be able to stimulate 
multiple regions together hence could focus on many things.
comments.author: manish goel

comments.text:
+manish goel Lets entertain the infinite energy thing you came up with:

say: you speak two languages plus you have memories from your life plus you 
know how to play the guitar plus you can order your body to run plus you 
can drive plus you have your job knowledge, plus you know how to read plus 
you know how to ....

Apart from your body's limit on the number of things it can do at once,you 
will need to do all these things at one moment together to use 100% of your 
brain, there are compartments in the brain where different things are 
placed, this is why using 100% of your brain in one task is impossible! it 
means you will have to forget all other things to allow that one moment to 
happen. Afterwards, you will have to learn how to control your pee and 
bowel movements again, how to speak again,, how to read again, how to.... 
all again from zero.
comments.author: Jonathan Lyng

comments.text:
My point is, what if we start to use the entire brain simultaneously? It 
won't affect the current task, and it will have other benefits.
comments.author: manish goel

comments.text:
Different areas of the brain are specialised for different tasks. The 
reason we only use a small proportion of our brain at any given time, is 
that it is not necessary for areas unrelated to the task to be being used. 
For example, there's no point in a part of your brain specialised in making 
cupcakes being active, when you are taking a maths test.
comments.author: Lawrence Parry

comments.text:
You people are all stupid. Data is there yet you dont interpret it well. If 
you look at how the brain functions (and the body too, in general)you would

people are not capable of sustaining high levels because their tissues are 
not charged enough. In chinese electricity of body is called chi. It is all 
the same but we have yin and yang chi. We generate yang chi outside the 
body when muscles are relaxed. With time it builds amd becomes concentrated 
like gravity. Then it slowly goes inside the tissues and bone where it 
stays with the cells as 'background energy' or 'maintenence energy'. This 
is then yin chi. This is why young people when the ejaculate and loose all 
their yang chi they feel energised because yin or stagnated chi comes out. 
It should come out through exercise and emotion not physical stimulus. Old 
people with not much yin chi or 'energy reserves' get considerably tired 
for the next few weeks!. So back ti brsin, it baturally needs more yin chi 
because of its active tissue. Through meditation and such you can save 
energy in the brain and for a while it has energy and you feel lightheaded. 
This is because the brain RARELY ever gets replentished with nornal humans. 
There are sexual practices where you get excited (collect a lot of energy 
outside - make it yang) and you send it to the mental centers to 
rejuvenate. That is one of the few times ur brain gets to 'breath'. In that 
case you taste a little what it is like to enlightened. <-common practice

do. If you don't know the maximum potential undiscovered areas in your

consideration the fact that we think we know all but we probably can't. :)

more, not 40%.

easier method for processing food and other energy resources?﻿

comments.text:
+Jozef Gjoni It would render us useless, and turn the most simple task in 
to a living nightmare. Let's say you would use 100% of your brain to 
pick-up a mug, you would use all of you r frontal lobe to analyse the 
optimal way to grab this mug (angle, inclination, distance...), then your 
limbic system would send all previous memories of you picking-up a mug, 
whit all the emotions attached to this action... o.O

comments.text:
I am not sure if this actually debunks the 10% of your brain myth. As it 
states in the video itself "1-16% of cells in your brain are active at any 
given moment," so in a certain perspective, the 10% myth is accurate. The 
distinction is simply that you are able to use all of your brain, but not 
at all at once.﻿
